title: Zooz 700 Series Z-Wave Plus 0-10 V Dimmer ZEN54 | Z-Wave Hub Required (Sold Separately)

product_information.Best Sellers Rank: Best Sellers Rank:  #40,004 in Tools & Home Improvement (See Top 100 in Tools & Home Improvement)    #386 in Dimmer Switches       #386 in Dimmer Switches

description: 0-10 V LED DRIVERS ONLY: Use with 0-10 V LED drivers up to 200 mA only. Do NOT use with 120 LED bulbs!SPECIFICATIONS:Model Number: ZEN54Z-Wave Signal Frequency: 908.42 MHzPower: 120-240 VAC, 50/60 HzMax Load: 4 A, 480W at 120V, 960 W at 240VZ-Wave Range: Up to 300 feet line of sightDimensions: 1.5" tall, 1.4" wide, 0.7" deepOperating Temperature: 32-104° F (0-40° C)Installation and Use: Indoor only  Will it work with my smart speakerSmart speakers are not Z-Wave controllers so you will need a compatible Z-Wave hub to control this device with voice commands.Smart speaker compatible Z-Wave hubs include:Z-Box Hubcompatible with SmartThingsHome Assistant (Z-Wave JS)HomeSeerHubitat
product_category: Tools & Home Improvement›Electrical›Switches & Dimmers›Wall Switches›Dimmer Switches
feature_bullets: Z-WAVE FOR 0-10 V LED DRIVERS: Control your 0-10 V LED drivers from your smartphone or automatically with smart rules. Instantly dim up or down, adjust brightness levels, and manage the length and intensity of light with ease. Z-Wave hub required, sold separately.

GET MORE OUT OF IT: Customize your dimmer with minimum brightness and maximum brightness settings. Built-in relay to turn the LED driver on and off to accommodate 1-10 and 0-10 V drivers. SmartStart and S2 authentication offer a truly protected smart home.

LONG RANGE READY: If your hub and automation software support Z-Wave Long Range, you'll get extended coverage without network lags and dropouts! And for traditional set-ups, the built-in signal repeater keeps your mesh networks stable and fast.

EASY INSTALLATION: Pigtail wires included to save you time when wiring the dimmer for an hassle-free set-up. This product is backed by a lifetime US based support from Zooz and a 5-year warranty once registered.

HUB COMPATIBILITY: This is an advanced Z-Wave device and it requires an updated Z-Wave hub to display correctly. It was tested to work well with the Z-Box Hub (recommended for Zooz devices), Hubitat with custom driver, Home Assistant (Z-Wave JS), and it's compatible with SmartThings through a custom edge driver (available through the Zooz support portal).

customers_say: Customers find the relay works well with Hubitat and appreciate its compact design that fits perfectly in 1-gang boxes. The installation process is straightforward, with clear instructions and quick pairing with Home Assistant. The device receives positive feedback for its functionality, with one customer noting it allows switch and relay operations to work independently. However, customers report mixed experiences with reliability, with some units failing after less than two months, and issues with switch input failure. Compatibility is also mixed, with some customers having trouble pairing it with their Z-Wave controllers.AI Generated from the text of customer reviews

customer_reviews.rating: 5.0 out of 5 stars5.0 out of 5 stars
customer_reviews.review_title: 5.0 out of 5 starsWorks great with Z-Wave and Home Assistant
customer_reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on May 3, 2025
customer_reviews.review_snippet: It took me a while to figure out how to pair it with my Home Assistant setup, but I went through their troubleshooting page and got it on the second try.  The final solution  to pairing it was to follow their instructions on their website - not sure if I can link it in this review, but I used DuckDuckGo to search for Zooz 800 ZEN55 "home assistant" and followed the instructions on that page.  The final solution was to click the buttons very quickly - I think I was too slow before - and I did a reset (I think) with five quick clicks, then re-added with 3 quick clicks.  The whole thing easily fit back into the smoke detector enclosure, and I tested it and it worked well.It's nice to have the piece of mind of knowing I'll get an alert on my phone if there is an issue, but without the privacy implications of using it with Google or another company.

customer_reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on May 29, 2025
customer_reviews.review_snippet: If you need a 10v dimmer for Zwave home automation this is what you want. If you do not know what a 10v dimmer is then you do not need this. The unit is small and easily fits in a single-gang box with a standard toggle switch. When paring, I was pressing the pair button too slow so if it won't pair then speed up the cadence of the triple press.

customer_reviews.review_title: 5.0 out of 5 starsGreat safety monitoring addition to smart home
customer_reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on May 24, 2025
customer_reviews.review_snippet: Installed easily with my smoke detector, connected to home assistant via a Z wave stick quickly and easily. There are no default alarms or alerts via home assistant but it was quick and easy for me to create a rule that if the dc detector indicates smoke or fire it will sent an alert to my phone. Tested via the test button on the smoke detector and it sent the alarm every time!

customer_reviews.review_title: 5.0 out of 5 starsThese are easy to configure and install.  Read the directions and don't guess the color code.
customer_reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on May 10, 2025
customer_reviews.review_snippet: This is easy to install.  On home Assistant scan the barcode, wire it in following the diagrams and it shows up ready to use.  it is small and easy to hide.  I like to use it with Wago connectors to make it easier to install and maintain.  I have no issues with connectivity and it seems to make the network stronger since it is a wired in node in the network.

customer_reviews.review_title: 5.0 out of 5 starsSmartThings Compatible Zooz Relay: Easy Installation, Silent Operation, Perfect Fit for 1-Gang Box
customer_reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on March 23, 2025
customer_reviews.review_snippet: I installed this Mar/2025 smart home device using the SmartThings hub v2. I have nine smoke detectors in my house.On the first link, I pressed the button three times to connect the device to my hub. However, I encountered an issue because the hub connected but didn’t function correctly. After researching, I discovered that I needed to install the Zooz driver first on my hub.When I attempted to update the driver in the hub, I couldn’t switch to the newly installed Zooz driver. Consequently, I had to put the device in exclusion mode and remove it from the hub. Next, I re-added the Zooz relay, and the device connected immediately with the correct driver.The relay produces no noise and fits perfectly in a 1-gang box, even though the box contains three Romex wires.

customer_reviews.review_title: 1.0 out of 5 starsIt is tiny, but there are flaws
customer_reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on April 4, 2023
customer_reviews.review_snippet: Let's start with the positives:* This thing is tiny. It packs two switch inputs and two relays where other manufacturers fit one* The price is about 40% less than other Z-Wave double switches* Lots of options for setup in Home Assistant, though this is a double-edged sword. Keep reading.The negatives:* The wimpy 5A relays put some pretty serious restrictions on where you can use this. A ceiling fan comes close to maxing out the relay rating. Definitely do not connect this thing to a switched outlet or anywhere else you can't guarantee a current draw under 5A. This limitation should be more clearly marked on the packaging. For example, you should definitely not use these to control a switched outlet. Someone might plug in a high current device in that outlet and cause a major problem.* Makes a little bit of a humming/buzzing noise. You won't hear it once the device is squirreled away inside a wall box, but I could definitely hear all three units I bought when I had them hooked up in the open (with all exposed wiring covered in Wago connectors) for pairing.* The default switch setup is a little confusing out of the box. I suspect the most common use for these, by a wide margin, is connecting them to existing light toggle switches. The switch inputs on all three of my units were not set that way by default. I was initially very confused when I got the switches hooked up, flipped the lights on with the physical switch, flipped them off with Home Assistant, and then had to hit the switch twice to get them to turn on again. I had to go into the device options in Home Assistant to get the switch inputs set as toggles (I don't remember what the initial setting was). I have lots of Wi-Fi, Zigbee, and Z-Wave smart switches and these are the only ones that weren't set up for toggle inputs by default. It is a minor issue, but I bet the manufacturer gets a lot of these things returned by confused customers that don't have patience for tinkering.Update: I have installed three units inside wall boxes in my house and all of them have had incidents where they completely stop working until I turn off the circuit breaker and turn it back on. When this happens the unit is unresponsive in Home Assistant AND the physical switch stops working. This is completely unacceptable.

customer_reviews.review_title: 4.0 out of 5 starsGreat idea and saves space in junction box
customer_reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on February 14, 2025
customer_reviews.review_snippet: Nice space saver compared to complete switch replacements, but you have to make sure you download the proper driver for smart things as it won’t work with the default driver.

customer_reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on May 19, 2025
